diagnoses.name: Acute Glomerulonephritis
diagnoses.description: An inflammation of the glomeruli, which are the parts of the kidney that filter blood. It can lead to symptoms such as edema, hematuria, and hypertension.

diagnoses.name: Systemic Lupus Erythematosus (SLE)
diagnoses.description: A chronic autoimmune disease that can affect the skin, joints, kidneys, brain, and other organs, causing a wide range of symptoms, including edema, anemia, and leukocytosis.

diagnoses.name: Rheumatic Fever
diagnoses.description: An inflammatory disease that can develop as a complication of inadequately treated strep throat or scarlet fever. Symptoms may include arthritis, fever, and heart problems.

diagnoses.name: Leptospirosis
diagnoses.description: A bacterial infection that can lead to kidney damage, liver failure, and other symptoms like conjunctivitis, anemia, and leukocytosis.

diagnoses.name: Henoch-Schonlein Purpura
diagnoses.description: An inflammation of the blood vessels (vasculitis) that can cause abdominal pain, rash, joint pain, and kidney problems.

diagnoses.name: Goodpasture Syndrome
diagnoses.description: An autoimmune disorder in which antibodies attack the lungs and kidneys, leading to bleeding from the lungs and kidney failure.

diagnoses.name: Sickle Cell Disease
diagnoses.description: A genetic disorder that leads to the production of abnormal hemoglobin. It can cause anemia, pain, and organ damage due to the blockage of blood flow.

diagnoses.name: Acute Interstitial Nephritis
diagnoses.description: A kidney condition characterized by the swelling of the kidneys due to a variety of causes, including medication reactions or infections.

diagnoses.name: Polyarteritis Nodosa
diagnoses.description: A serious blood vessel disease where small and medium-sized arteries become swollen and damaged. It can affect any organ in the body, leading to a wide range of symptoms.

diagnoses.name: Kawasaki Disease
diagnoses.description: An acute, usually self-limited vasculitis of childhood, though it can also occur in adults. It's characterized by fever, rash, swelling of the hands and feet, red eyes, and changes in the lips and mouth.

diagnoses: Drug reaction with eosinophilia and systemic symptoms (DRESS syndrome)
Drug Reactions with Eosinophilia and Systemic Symptoms (DRESS) Syndrome
Drug reaction with eosinophilia and systemic symptoms (DRESS) syndrome

diagnoses.name: Systemic Lupus Erythematosus (SLE)
diagnoses.rationale: Discoid rash and proteinuria are classic for SLE, and patients often present with fever, various types of rashes including maculopapular types, and dyspigmentation due to skin involvement.

diagnoses.name: Dermatomyositis
diagnoses.rationale: Dermatomyositis can present with rash, dyspigmentation (like Gottron's sign or heliotrope rash), and systemic features like fever. Proteinuria may indicate associated renal involvement.

diagnoses.name: Mixed Connective Tissue Disease
diagnoses.rationale: This disease often presents with features similar to SLE, including discoid rash, maculopapular rash, fever, and can sometimes cause kidney involvement leading to proteinuria.

diagnoses.name: Drug Reactions with Eosinophilia and Systemic Symptoms (DRESS) Syndrome
diagnoses.rationale: Features can include fever, rashes such as maculopapular rash, and internal organ involvement which can lead to proteinuria. Dyspigmentation can occur as a part of the skin's healing process.

diagnoses.name: Lyme Disease
diagnoses.rationale: Early disseminated Lyme disease can present with fever, erythema migrans which might be confused with discoid or maculopapular rashes, and potentially renal involvement.

diagnoses.name: Secondary Syphilis
diagnoses.rationale: Can present with fever, maculopapular rash, and systemic involvement including renal (proteinuria). Lesions may lead to dyspigmentation as they heal.

diagnoses.name: HIV Acute Retroviral Syndrome
diagnoses.rationale: Early HIV infection can cause maculopapular rash, fever, and renal involvement leading to proteinuria. Dyspigmentation might be witnessed as a secondary effect from rash healing.

diagnoses.name: Hepatitis B
diagnoses.rationale: Acute infection can sometimes present with a maculopapular rash, fever, and kidney problems, including proteinuria. Skin changes might include dyspigmentation.

diagnoses.name: Leptospirosis
diagnoses.rationale: This can present with fever, rashes, and kidney involvement leading to proteinuria. Though discoid rash and dyspigmentation are less commonly associated, they can be present in severe cases.

diagnoses.name: Sarcoidosis
diagnoses.rationale: Sarcoidosis can present with a wide array of symptoms including fever, lung involvement, and skin manifestations such as lupus pernio that might be mistaken for discoid rash; kidney involvement can cause proteinuria.

diagnoses: Rickettsial infections (E.g., Typhus, Rocky Mountain spotted fever)
Evans Syndrome (Autoimmune Hemolytic Anemia with Immune Thrombocytopenia)
Evans syndrome (autoimmune hemolytic anemia with immune thrombocytopenia)
Diabetes Mellitus Type 1 or 2 with Nephropathy
Viral infections (e.g., Dengue Fever, Zika Virus)
Evans syndrome (autoimmune hemolytic anemia combined with thrombocytopenia or neutropenia)
Viral infections (e.g., Hepatitis B, Hepatitis C)
Rheumatoid Arthritis with Associated Interstitial Lung Disease
Neurological infection or inflammation (e.g., meningitis, encephalitis)
Malignancy (cancer affecting the brain, spinal cord, lymphatic system)
Autoimmune disorders (e.g., Multiple Sclerosis, Systemic Lupus Erythematosus)

symptoms: dyspnea with normal pulmonary function tests

diagnoses: Infectious diseases (e.g., bacterial, viral, fungal infections)
Secondary immunodeficiency due to medication or illness

diagnoses.name: Chronic Idiopathic Urticaria
diagnoses.description: A condition characterized by hives that last more than six weeks with unknown cause, often associated with angioedema. Anxiety, non-restorative sleep, and irritability can be common due to the chronic nature and discomfort of the disease.

diagnoses.name: Generalized Anxiety Disorder (GAD)
diagnoses.description: A mental disorder characterized by excessive worry about various aspects of daily life, accompanied by physical symptoms like irritability and sleep disturbance. Patients may experience heightened susceptibility to infections due to chronic stress.

diagnoses.name: Hypothyroidism
diagnoses.description: A common thyroid disorder where the body lacks sufficient thyroid hormones, leading to angioedema, increased susceptibility to infections, non-restorative sleep, and mood changes such as irritability.

diagnoses.name: Hereditary Angioedema
diagnoses.description: A rare genetic disorder characterized by recurrent episodes of severe swelling (angioedema). Patients may experience anxiety due to unpredictable swelling episodes and poor quality of sleep due to discomfort.

diagnoses.name: Depression
diagnoses.description: A mental health disorder characterized by persistently depressed mood or loss of interest in activities, causing significant impairment in daily life. Symptoms can include irritability, sleep disturbance, and a weakened immune system.

diagnoses.name: Chronic Fatigue Syndrome (CFS)
diagnoses.description: A complex disorder characterized by extreme fatigue not improved by rest and worsened by physical or mental activity. It often presents with sleep abnormalities, anxiety, irritability, and a higher susceptibility to infections.

diagnoses.name: Sleep Apnea
diagnoses.description: A sleep disorder in which breathing repeatedly stops and starts, leading to non-restorative sleep, daytime fatigue, irritability, and potentially increasing anxiety. Can also impact immune function over time.

diagnoses.name: Chronic Stress
diagnoses.description: A condition of persistent mental and emotional stress that can lead to a range of physical health issues, including angioedema, poor sleep quality, increased risk of infections, anxiety, and irritability.

diagnoses.name: Post-Traumatic Stress Disorder (PTSD)
diagnoses.description: A disorder characterized by failure to recover after experiencing or witnessing a terrifying event, leading to symptoms such as severe anxiety, disturbing dreams or flashbacks, irritability, and sleep disturbances.

diagnoses.name: Systemic Lupus Erythematosus (SLE)
diagnoses.description: An autoimmune disease in which the immune system attacks its own tissues, causing widespread inflammation and damage to organs and tissues. Symptoms include fatigue, sleep disturbances, anxiety, irritability, and increased risk of infections.

diagnoses: Inflammatory bowel disease (Crohn's disease and ulcerative colitis)
Inflammatory bowel disease (Crohn's disease and ulcerative colitis)
PANDAS (Pediatric Autoimmune Neuropsychiatric Disorders Associated with Streptococcal infections)
Chronic liver disease (e.g., cirrhosis leading to cognitive dysfunction known as hepatic encephalopathy)

diagnoses.name: Major Depression
diagnoses.description: A mental disorder characterized by persistently depressed mood or loss of interest in activities, causing significant impairment in daily life. It can manifest physically as non-restorative sleep and contribute to stress-related behaviors such as obsessive-compulsive tendencies.

diagnoses.name: Generalized Anxiety Disorder (GAD)
diagnoses.description: A disorder characterized by excessive, uncontrollable worry about various aspects of life, often manifesting with physical symptoms such as difficulty sleeping, hyperactivity, and sometimes leading to stress-related ulcers.

diagnoses.name: Obsessive-Compulsive Disorder (OCD)
diagnoses.description: A disorder where individuals experience unwanted and intrusive thoughts (obsessions) that lead them to carry out behavior rituals (compulsions), including hyperactivity as an effort to relieve anxiety.

diagnoses.name: Attention-Deficit/Hyperactivity Disorder (ADHD)
diagnoses.description: A neurodevelopmental disorder affecting both children and adults characterized by persistent issues with attention, hyperactivity, and impulsiveness. Difficulty focusing vision can sometimes be associated due to attention problems.

diagnoses.name: Bipolar Disorder
diagnoses.description: A disorder associated with episodes of mood swings ranging from depressive lows to manic highs. The highs may include symptoms like reduced need for sleep, hyperactivity, and obsessive focus on specific goals.

diagnoses.name: Sleep Disorders
diagnoses.description: This encompasses a range of disorders leading to troubles with sleep quality, timing, and restfulness, such as insomnia, which might lead to non-restorative sleep.

diagnoses.name: Peptic Ulcer Disease
diagnoses.description: A condition where ulcers form on the lining of the stomach, esophagus, or small intestine, typically caused by Helicobacter pylori infection or long-term use of non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs). Stress and anxiety can exacerbate symptoms.

diagnoses.name: Anemia
diagnoses.description: A condition marked by a deficiency of red blood cells or of hemoglobin in the blood, leading to fatigue, weakness, and other symptoms like difficulty focusing.

diagnoses.name: Chronic Fatigue Syndrome (CFS)
diagnoses.description: A complex disorder characterized by extreme fatigue that can't be explained by any underlying medical condition. The fatigue worsens with physical or mental activity but doesn't improve with rest, often accompanying non-restorative sleep.

diagnoses.name: Thyroid Disorders
diagnoses.description: Dysfunctions of the thyroid gland, such as hypothyroidism or hyperthyroidism, can affect metabolism and energy levels, potentially causing symptoms like hyperactivity, difficulty focusing, and changes in sleep patterns.

diagnoses.name: Allergic reaction
diagnoses.description: An immune system response to a foreign substance that's not typically harmful to your body. These foreign substances are called allergens. Kounis syndrome is a type of allergic reaction affecting the coronary arteries.

diagnoses.name: Systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE)
diagnoses.description: A chronic autoimmune disease that can cause inflammation and pain in any part of your body. It's often characterized by skin rashes, joint pain, and inflammation of organs such as the kidneys (lupus nephritis), which could relate to chronic kidney disease.

diagnoses.name: Sjögren's syndrome
diagnoses.description: An immune system disorder characterized by dry eyes and dry mouth. It can also cause lymphadenitis due to chronic inflammation.

diagnoses.name: Rheumatoid arthritis
diagnoses.description: A chronic inflammatory disorder affecting many joints, including those in the hands and feet. It's an autoimmune disorder that can cause a wide variety of symptoms, including headache and eye irritation.

diagnoses.name: Sarcoidosis
diagnoses.description: An inflammatory disease that can affect multiple organs in the body, primarily the lungs and lymph nodes. It can cause lymphadenitis, eye irritation, and can potentially affect kidney function.

diagnoses.name: Lyme disease
diagnoses.description: An infectious disease caused by the Borrelia bacterium which is spread by ticks. It can cause a wide range of symptoms, including headache, eye irritation, and kidney disease.

diagnoses.name: Behçet's disease
diagnoses.description: A rare disorder causing blood vessel inflammation throughout your body. It can lead to numerous signs and symptoms that may seem unrelated at first, including headaches, eye inflammation, and potentially affecting kidney function.

diagnoses.name: Granulomatosis with polyangiitis
diagnoses.description: A rare disorder that causes inflammation of the blood vessels in your organs, which can lead to complications in the kidneys (kidney disease), as well as eye irritation and headaches.

diagnoses.name: Churg-Strauss syndrome
diagnoses.description: Also known as eosinophilic granulomatosis with polyangiitis, it's a disorder that causes inflammation of blood vessels. This can lead to asthma, headaches, and kidney disease.

diagnoses.name: Diabetes mellitus
diagnoses.description: A group of diseases that affect how your body uses blood sugar (glucose). Although not directly related to the symptoms, poorly controlled diabetes can exacerbate or contribute to the development of chronic kidney disease and potentially cause headache and vision issues.

diagnoses.name: Hemochromatosis
diagnoses.description: A genetic disorder causing the body to absorb too much iron from the diet. The excess iron is stored in various organs, particularly the liver. Hyperferritinemia is a common finding in hemochromatosis.

diagnoses.name: Langerhans Cell Histiocytosis
diagnoses.description: A disorder where the body produces too many immature Langerhans cells which can form tumors or damage organs. It can lead to a variety of symptoms including skin lesions, bone pain, and memory problems.

diagnoses.name: Chronic Myelogenous Leukemia (CML)
diagnoses.description: A type of cancer that starts in the blood-forming cells of the bone marrow and invades the blood. It can cause basophilia and is associated with an increased risk of various symptoms including memory problems.

diagnoses.name: Myelodysplastic Syndromes
diagnoses.description: A group of disorders caused by poorly formed or dysfunctional blood cells. Symptoms may include memory problems due to cerebral emboli from abnormal blood cells, and hyperferritinemia.

diagnoses.name: Behçet’s Disease
diagnoses.description: A rare disorder causing blood vessel inflammation throughout the body, leading to numerous symptoms, including mouth sores (leukoplakia-like), skin problems, and memory issues.

diagnoses.name: Polycythemia Vera
diagnoses.description: A blood disorder in which the bone marrow makes too many red blood cells. It can lead to an elevated red cell count, basophilia, and is occasionally associated with hyperferritinemia.

diagnoses.name: HIV/AIDS
diagnoses.description: The virus can cause a wide range of symptoms and opportunistic infections. Oral leukoplakia, memory loss, and various skin problems including alopecia are common in advanced stages.

diagnoses.name: Lupus
diagnoses.description: An autoimmune disease that can affect almost any part of the body, including the skin (alopecia), joints, and other organs, leading to a wide variety of symptoms.

diagnoses.name: Aplastic Anemia
diagnoses.description: A condition that occurs when the body stops producing enough new blood cells. It can cause fatigue, memory problems due to anemia, and also alopecia in some cases due to treatment or the disease itself.

diagnoses.name: Iron Overload Disorders
diagnoses.description: Conditions including hereditary hemochromatosis where there is excessive accumulation of iron in the body tissues leading to hyperferritinemia. Symptoms vary based on the organs affected.

diagnoses: Depressive Disorder (Major Depressive Disorder, Clinical Depression)

diagnoses.name: Infectious Mononucleosis
diagnoses.description: Also known as 'mono', this infection is often caused by the Epstein-Barr virus and can lead to fever, sore throat, swollen lymph glands, and fatigue.

diagnoses.name: Bacterial Pneumonia
diagnoses.description: A bacterial infection that inflames the air sacs in one or both lungs, which may fill with fluid.

diagnoses.name: Sepsis
diagnoses.description: A potentially life-threatening condition caused by the body's response to an infection, which can lead to tissue damage, organ failure, and death.

diagnoses.name: Lymphoma
diagnoses.description: A type of cancer that begins in infection-fighting cells of the immune system, called lymphocytes. These cells are in the lymph nodes, spleen, thymus, bone marrow, and other parts of the body.

diagnoses.name: Acute HIV Infection
diagnoses.description: The early stage of HIV infection that happens within 2 to 4 weeks after being infected with HIV. Symptoms can be similar to the flu or other viral illnesses.

diagnoses.name: Streptococcal Infection
diagnoses.description: An infection with streptococcus bacteria. Can range from mild skin infections to severe infections of the blood or organs.

diagnoses.name: Systemic Lupus Erythematosus (SLE)
diagnoses.description: A chronic autoimmune disease that can cause inflammation and pain in any part of the body.

diagnoses.name: Tuberculosis
diagnoses.description: A potentially serious infectious disease that mainly affects the lungs. The bacteria that cause tuberculosis are spread from one person to another through tiny droplets released into the air via coughs and sneezes.

diagnoses.name: Allergic Reactions
diagnoses.description: An immune system response to a foreign substance that's not typically harmful to your body. These foreign substances are called allergens. Can cause various symptoms, including angioedema.

diagnoses.name: Anaphylaxis
diagnoses.description: A severe, potentially life-threatening allergic reaction. It can occur within seconds or minutes of exposure to something you're allergic to.

diagnoses.name: Viral Infection
diagnoses.reasoning: Common viral infections can lead to symptoms like fatigue, laryngitis (as part of a sore throat), and dysgeusia (altered taste). Tinnitus and vision issues could result from the overall stress of the infection on the body.

diagnoses.name: Chronic Fatigue Syndrome
diagnoses.reasoning: Characterized by severe, prolonged fatigue that is not relieved by rest and is not directly caused by other medical conditions. Tinnitus and difficulty focusing vision can be associated symptoms.

diagnoses.name: Multiple Sclerosis
diagnoses.reasoning: A disease where the immune system eats away at the protective covering of nerves. Symptom manifestation is vast and can include fatigue, difficulty focusing (due to optic neuritis), and tinnitus.

diagnoses.name: Depression
diagnoses.reasoning: Mental health condition that can cause extreme fatigue, difficulty focusing, changes in sensory perception (such as dysgeusia), and sometimes tinnitus as a symptom or side effect of medication.

diagnoses.name: Medication Side Effects
diagnoses.reasoning: Certain medications can cause side effects such as fatigue, dysgeusia, tinnitus, difficulty focusing vision, and even symptoms that mimic laryngitis.

diagnoses.name: Fibromyalgia
diagnoses.reasoning: A condition characterized by widespread musculoskeletal pain accompanied by fatigue, sleep, memory, and mood issues. Some patients report tinnitus and difficulties with vision.

diagnoses.name: Sjögren's Syndrome
diagnoses.reasoning: An autoimmune disease that attacks glands responsible for keeping the eyes, mouth, and other parts of the body moist and lubricated, leading to fatigue and potentially affecting sensory functions.

diagnoses.name: Iron Deficiency Anemia
diagnoses.reasoning: Causes fatigue due to insufficient hemoglobin in red blood cells. It may also cause tinnitus, and possibly dysgeusia. Laryngitis isn’t directly linked but could appear if the body’s overall strength is compromised.

diagnoses.name: Meniere’s Disease
diagnoses.reasoning: A disorder of the inner ear that can lead to dizzy spells (and possibly trouble focusing vision as a result) and tinnitus. Fatigue may occur, especially after severe vertigo attacks.

diagnoses.name: Hypothyroidism
diagnoses.reasoning: A condition in which the thyroid gland doesn't produce enough thyroid hormones. Symptoms include fatigue, and possibly tinnitus. Dysgeusia and vision problems can also occur in severe or chronic cases.

diagnoses: Hashimoto's Thyroiditis leading to transient hyperthyroidism
Gastrointestinal Ulceration secondary to NSAID usage
Secondary Immunodeficiency Disease due to underlying condition or treatment

symptoms: dyspnea with normal pulmonary function tests

diagnoses.name: Sjögren's Syndrome
diagnoses.description: An autoimmune disease that often presents with dry eyes and dry mouth, which could indirectly lead to urinary tract infections due to decreased mucosal secretions. It may also be associated with osteopenia due to chronic inflammation.

diagnoses.name: Autoimmune Disorders
diagnoses.description: Various autoimmune disorders can manifest with a combination of symptoms including hearing loss, thrombocytosis, dry eyes, and more. They could contribute indirectly to other symptoms like urinary tract infections.

diagnoses.name: Chronic Kidney Disease
diagnoses.description: While not directly causing all symptoms, chronic kidney disease can lead to osteopenia and contribute to a higher risk of urinary tract infections. It must be evaluated in the context of other systemic symptoms.

diagnoses.name: Elderly Age-related Changes
diagnoses.description: In older adults, a combination of dry eyes, hearing loss, urinary tract infections, thrombocytosis, and osteopenia could represent age-related changes rather than a specific disease process.

diagnoses.name: Diabetes Mellitus
diagnoses.description: Diabetes can lead to a host of complications including urinary tract infections, hearing loss, and contribute to conditions like osteopenia due to changes in blood flow and nutrient delivery.

diagnoses.name: Rheumatoid Arthritis
diagnoses.description: An autoimmune disease that can cause systemic symptoms including osteopenia, thrombocytosis, and dry eyes (secondary Sjögren syndrome). Urinary tract infections could occur more frequently due to immunosuppressive treatments.

diagnoses.name: Lupus (Systemic Lupus Erythematosus)
diagnoses.description: An autoimmune disease that can present with a wide variety of symptoms, including those specified. It’s known for affecting multiple body systems.

diagnoses.name: Vitamin D Deficiency
diagnoses.description: Vitamin D plays a critical role in bone health, potentially impacting conditions such as osteopenia. Deficiency might indirectly influence the severity or occurrence of other conditions due to its role in immune function.

diagnoses.name: Hypothyroidism
diagnoses.description: Can cause or worsen symptoms such as hearing loss and contribute to osteopenia. It can also influence the body's immune response, potentially affecting susceptibility to infections.

diagnoses.name: Malignancy
diagnoses.description: Certain cancers can present with a broad array of nonspecific symptoms, including thrombocytosis, which is an increase in platelet count. It's critical to rule out malignancies when faced with multiple, seemingly unrelated symptoms.

symptoms: dyspnea with normal pulmonary function tests

diagnoses: Squamous cell carcinoma of the conjunctiva

symptoms: dyspnea with normal pulmonary function tests
dyspnea with normal pulmonary function tests

diagnoses: Drug reaction (with eosinophilia and systemic symptoms)
Allergic reaction to food or medication
Urinary Tract Infection (with delirium for incontinence)
Systemic Lupus Erythematosus (with gastrointestinal and respiratory involvement)

diagnoses.name: Allergic reaction
diagnoses.description: An immune system response to a foreign substance that's not typically harmful to your body. These substances are called allergens. They can include certain foods, pollen, or pet dander. The symptoms include hives, sneezing, rhinorrhea, abdominal cramps, and hypotension as part of an anaphylactic reaction.

diagnoses.name: Anaphylaxis
diagnoses.description: A severe, potentially life-threatening allergic reaction. It can occur within seconds or minutes of exposure to something you're allergic to, such as peanuts or bee stings. Symptoms include hives, hypotension, difficulty breathing, and gastrointestinal symptoms like abdominal cramps.

diagnoses.name: Food allergy
diagnoses.description: An immune system response following the consumption of a particular food. Symptoms can include hives, sneezing, rhinorrhea, abdominal pain, and rare cases might progress to anaphylaxis, including hypotension.

diagnoses.name: Drug allergy
diagnoses.description: An immune system's adverse reaction to a medication. Common symptoms include hives, rash, fever, sneezing, rhinorrhea, and in severe cases, anaphylaxis which could lead to hypotension.

diagnoses.name: Urticaria (Hives)
diagnoses.description: A skin reaction that causes itchy welts. Hives can be triggered by many situations and substances, including exposure to certain foods, medications, and stress. Accompanying symptoms can include abdominal cramps, sneezing, and rhinorrhea in cases associated with systemic reaction.

diagnoses.name: Mast cell disorders
diagnoses.description: Conditions that affect mast cells, part of the immune system. Symptoms can include abdominal cramps, flushing, hypotension, hives, and rhinorrhea due to the release of mast cell mediators.

diagnoses.name: Insect bite or sting allergy
diagnoses.description: An allergic reaction to the venom of stinging or biting insects. Symptoms can range from mild, including hives and rhinorrhea, to severe, such as anaphylaxis, which can include hypotension and abdominal cramps.

diagnoses.name: Hay Fever (Allergic Rhinitis)
diagnoses.description: An allergic response causing itchy, watery eyes, sneezing, and other similar symptoms. While less commonly associated with abdominal cramps or hypotension, it might coexist with other allergic reactions that do.

diagnoses.name: Contact dermatitis
diagnoses.description: A skin rash caused by contact with a certain substance. Symptoms can include hives, which may be accompanied by other allergic reaction symptoms such as sneezing and rhinorrhea. Severe cases can lead to systemic reactions.

diagnoses.name: Latex allergy
diagnoses.description: An allergic reaction to certain proteins found in natural rubber latex. Symptoms can range from skin irritation, hives, sneezing, rhinorrhea to severe cases like anaphylactic shock, which might include hypotension and abdominal cramps.

diagnoses: Inflammatory Bowel Disease (e.g., Crohn's Disease, Ulcerative Colitis)
Inflammatory Bowel Disease (Crohn's Disease, Ulcerative Colitis)

diagnoses.name: Gastroenteritis
diagnoses.description: An inflammation of the digestive tract that causes vomiting and abdominal cramps. Can lead to dehydration and hypotension.

diagnoses.name: Sepsis
diagnoses.description: A life-threatening complication of an infection that can lead to tissue damage, organ failure, and death. Can cause hypotension and hypoxia.

diagnoses.name: Anaphylaxis
diagnoses.description: A severe, potentially life-threatening allergic reaction that can cause abdominal cramps, vomiting, hypotension, and hypoxia.

diagnoses.name: Acute Pancreatitis
diagnoses.description: Inflammation of the pancreas that typically causes abdominal pain, vomiting, and can lead to systemic complications like hypoxia and hypotension.

diagnoses.name: Toxic Shock Syndrome
diagnoses.description: A rare, life-threatening complication of certain bacterial infections. Symptoms include vomiting, hypotension, and multi-organ involvement leading to hypoxia.

diagnoses.name: Bowel Obstruction
diagnoses.description: A blockage in the intestines that can cause abdominal pain, vomiting, and if not treated, can lead to septic shock, causing hypotension and hypoxia.

diagnoses.name: Addison’s Disease
diagnoses.description: A disorder in which the adrenal glands don’t produce enough hormones. Symptoms can include abdominal pain, vomiting, hypotension, and if untreated, can lead to an Addisonian crisis, potentially causing hypoxia.

diagnoses.name: Pneumonia
diagnoses.description: An infection that inflames the air sacs in one or both lungs. While primarily respiratory, severe cases can cause systemic symptoms such as hypotension and hypoxia; abdominal cramps and vomiting can occur, especially in children.

diagnoses.name: Myocardial Infarction
diagnoses.description: A heart attack, which occurs when blood flow decreases or stops to a part of the heart, causing damage. Can lead to hypotension and hypoxia; less commonly, it may present with abdominal pain and vomiting.

diagnoses.name: Diabetic Ketoacidosis
diagnoses.description: A serious complication of diabetes characterized by hyperglycemia, ketosis, and acidosis. Can cause abdominal pain, vomiting, and if severe, can lead to hypotension and hypoxia.

diagnoses.name: Multiple Sclerosis
diagnoses.description: A chronic, typically progressive disease involving damage to the sheaths of nerve cells in the brain and spinal cord, symptoms may include numbness, impairment of speech and of muscular coordination, blurred vision and severe fatigue.

diagnoses.name: Migraine
diagnoses.description: A primary headache disorder characterized by recurrent headaches that are moderate to severe. Symptoms may include photophobia, phonophobia, nausea, vomiting, and exacerbation of symptoms with physical activity.

diagnoses.name: Transient Ischemic Attack (TIA)
diagnoses.description: Often called a 'mini-stroke', a TIA is a temporary period of symptoms similar to those of a stroke. Symptoms can include paralysis, speech difficulties, and mental confusion but do not result in lasting damage.

diagnoses.name: Optic Neuritis
diagnoses.description: Inflammation of the optic nerve that may cause a complete or partial loss of vision. It can be associated with eye pain, loss of color vision, and 'flashes' of light in the eye.

diagnoses.name: Guillain-Barré Syndrome
diagnoses.description: A rare neurological disorder in which the body's immune system mistakenly attacks part of its peripheral nervous system—the network of nerves located outside of the brain and spinal cord. Symptoms can quickly include weakness and tingling in the extremities.

diagnoses.name: Vitamin B12 Deficiency
diagnoses.description: Lack of B12 can lead to neurological issues, causing symptoms such as tingling in the hands and feet (paresthesia), weakness, fatigue, and visual disturbances like blurred vision.

diagnoses.name: Lupus (Systemic Lupus Erythematosus)
diagnoses.description: An autoimmune disease that occurs when your body's immune system attacks your own tissues and organs. Symptoms vary but can include fatigue, joint pain, rash, and fever. Neurological symptoms can include headaches, dizziness, memory disturbances, vision problems, and stroke.

diagnoses.name: Stroke
diagnoses.description: Occurs when the blood supply to part of the brain is interrupted or reduced, preventing brain tissue from getting oxygen and nutrients. Brain cells begin to die in minutes. Symptoms can include trouble walking, speaking, and understanding, as well as paralysis or numbness of the face, arm, or leg.

diagnoses.name: Brain Tumor
diagnoses.description: Any intracranial tumor caused by abnormal and uncontrolled cell division, either in the brain itself, the cranial nerves, the brain envelopes, skull, pituitary and pineal gland. Symptoms can vary greatly and involve neurological deficits such as weakness, sensory changes, and altered mental status.

diagnoses.name: Hypothyroidism
diagnoses.description: A condition in which your thyroid gland doesn't produce enough thyroid hormones. It can cause symptoms such as fatigue, weight gain, cold intolerance, joint and muscle pain, and also neurological symptoms like depression, memory issues, and paresthesia.

diagnoses.name: Migraine with aura
diagnoses.description: A type of headache characterized by recurrent attacks of moderate to severe throbbing and pulsating pain on one side of the head. The aura includes visual disturbances and other neurological symptoms that appear before the headache and last for about 20 to 60 minutes.

diagnoses.name: Stroke
diagnoses.description: Occurs when the blood supply to part of your brain is interrupted or reduced, preventing brain tissue from getting oxygen and nutrients. Brain cells begin to die within minutes. Symptoms may include sudden numbness, weakness, confusion, trouble speaking or understanding speech, and headache.

Often called a mini-stroke, a transient ischemic attack is a brief period of symptoms similar to those in a stroke. A TIA doesn't cause permanent damage. It's characterized by temporary stroke-like symptoms, often lasting less than one to two hours.

diagnoses.name: Brain tumor
diagnoses.description: A mass or growth of abnormal cells in your brain. Symptoms can vary greatly depending on the brain tumor's size, location, and rate of growth. Common symptoms include headaches, seizures, weakness, and cognitive or speech difficulties.

diagnoses.name: Epilepsy
diagnoses.description: A neurological disorder marked by sudden recurrent episodes of sensory disturbance, loss of consciousness, or convulsions, associated with abnormal electrical activity in the brain. It can manifest as episodes of scintillation and may sometimes lead to headaches, weakness, or speech disturbances.

diagnoses.name: Multiple sclerosis (MS)
diagnoses.description: A disease in which the immune system eats away at the protective covering of nerves. Symptoms can include fatigue, weakness, scintillation, and difficulties with coordination and speech.

diagnoses.name: Hemorrhagic stroke
diagnoses.description: Occurs when a blood vessel in your brain leaks or ruptures. Brain hemorrhages can result from many conditions affecting the brain. Symptoms can include sudden headache, weakness, aphasia, and altered consciousness.

diagnoses.name: Meningitis
diagnoses.description: An inflammation of the membranes (meninges) surrounding your brain and spinal cord. The swelling from meningitis typically triggers symptoms such as headache, fever, and a stiff neck.

diagnoses.name: Ischemic stroke
diagnoses.description: Caused by a blockage in an artery that supplies blood to the brain. The blockage reduces the blood flow and oxygen to the brain, leading to damage or death of brain cells. Symptoms include weakness, headache, aphasia, and difficulty seeing in one or both eyes.

diagnoses.name: Subarachnoid hemorrhage
diagnoses.description: A bleeding into the subarachnoid space—the area between the arachnoid membrane and the pia mater surrounding the brain. Symptoms can include a sudden, severe headache, often described as the 'worst headache' ever experienced, along with nausea, vomiting, and photophobia.

diagnoses.name: Migraine
diagnoses.description: A neurological condition that can cause multiple symptoms including severe headaches, nausea, numbness, and tingling sensations.

diagnoses.name: Multiple Sclerosis
diagnoses.description: A chronic autoimmune disease affecting the central nervous system, leading to symptoms like weakness, numbness, tingling, and balance issues.

diagnoses.name: Stroke
diagnoses.description: A medical condition occurring when the blood supply to part of the brain is interrupted, leading to symptoms such as headache, numbness, and weakness on one side of the body.

diagnoses.name: Guillain-Barre Syndrome
diagnoses.description: A rare neurological disorder in which the body's immune system mistakenly attacks the peripheral nerves, leading to weakness, numbness, and tingling.

diagnoses.name: Diabetic Neuropathy
diagnoses.description: A type of nerve damage that can occur with diabetes, characterized by numbness, tingling, and weakness, especially in the hands and feet.

diagnoses.name: Vitamin B12 Deficiency
diagnoses.description: A deficiency in Vitamin B12 can lead to neurological issues, including numbness, weakness, and problems with balance.

diagnoses.name: Meningitis
diagnoses.description: An inflammation of the protective membranes covering the brain and spinal cord, known as meninges. Symptoms can include headache, nausea, and numbness.

diagnoses.name: Lyme Disease
diagnoses.description: An infectious disease caused by the Borrelia bacterium, spread by ticks. It can cause a wide range of symptoms, including headache, numbness, and facial palsy.

diagnoses.name: Hypothyroidism
diagnoses.description: A condition in which the thyroid gland does not produce enough thyroid hormone, leading to symptoms like fatigue, weakness, and numbness.

diagnoses.name: Anxiety Disorders
diagnoses.description: While primarily psychological in nature, severe anxiety can also cause physical symptoms like numbness, tingling sensations, weakness, and headaches.

diagnoses.name: Migraine with Aura
diagnoses.description: A type of headache that is often accompanied by visual disturbances (aura), including symptoms like photophobia, scotoma, and sometimes weakness or language disturbances such as aphasia.

diagnoses.name: Stroke
diagnoses.description: A condition where poor blood flow to the brain results in cell death. Symptoms can include headache, weakness on one side of the body, difficulty speaking (aphasia), and visual problems including photophobia and scotoma.

diagnoses.name: Transient Ischemic Attack (TIA)
diagnoses.description: Often called a 'mini-stroke,' a TIA presents with symptoms similar to a stroke, including headache, weakness, aphasia, and visual disturbances, but these symptoms are temporary, typically lasting less than 24 hours.

diagnoses.name: Multiple Sclerosis
diagnoses.description: A chronic autoimmune condition affecting the central nervous system, leading to symptoms such as weakness, visual disturbances (scotoma, photophobia), and in some cases, speech difficulties including aphasia.

diagnoses.name: Brain Tumor
diagnoses.description: Tumors in the brain can press on nerve tissues and cause various symptoms depending on their location, including headaches, seizures, weakness, aphasia, and visual disturbances.

diagnoses.name: Meningitis
diagnoses.description: An inflammation of the protective membranes covering the brain and spinal cord, known as the meninges. Symptoms can include a severe headache, photophobia, weakness, and in severe cases, neurological deficits including aphasia.

diagnoses.name: Encephalitis
diagnoses.description: Inflammation of the brain, often caused by an infection, presenting with fever, headache, photophobia, weakness, and in some cases, seizures or aphasia.

diagnoses.name: Cerebral Venous Sinus Thrombosis
diagnoses.description: A blood clot in the brain's venous sinuses. It can cause headache, weakness, visual disturbances like scotoma, and in some cases, aphasia.

diagnoses.name: Posterior Reversible Encephalopathy Syndrome (PRES)
diagnoses.description: A syndrome characterized by headache, seizures, visual disturbances including scotoma, and sometimes weakness or aphasia. It is often reversible with treatment.

diagnoses.name: Epilepsy
diagnoses.description: A neurological disorder marked by sudden recurrent episodes of sensory disturbance, convulsions, aphasia, or loss of consciousness. Epileptic seizures can also lead to headaches, photophobia, and postictal weakness.

diagnoses.name: Multiple Sclerosis
diagnoses.description: A chronic, typically progressive disease involving damage to the sheaths of nerve cells in the brain and spinal cord, symptoms may include numbness, impairment of speech and of muscular coordination, blurred vision and severe fatigue.

diagnoses.name: Migraine with Aura
diagnoses.description: A type of migraine that involves neurological phenomena (aura) like visual disturbances (scotoma) before the head pain arrives. Other symptoms can include sensory changes, weakness, and language difficulty.

diagnoses.Mengeitis: Inflammation of the brain and spinal cord membranes, typically caused by an infection. Symptoms can include headache, fever, numbness, weakness, and hearing loss.

diagnoses.name: Stroke
diagnoses.description: Occurs when the blood supply to part of your brain is interrupted or reduced, preventing brain tissue from getting oxygen and nutrients. Symptoms can include headache, numbness or weakness in the face, arm, or leg, especially on one side of the body, and visual problems.

diagnoses.name: Transient Ischemic Attack
diagnoses.description: Often called a mini-stroke, a transient ischemic attack is a temporary period of symptoms similar to those of a stroke. Symptoms can include numbness or weakness in the face, arms or legs, especially on one side of the body, speech disturbances, and visual issues.

diagnoses.name: Acoustic Neuroma
diagnoses.description: A benign tumor that develops on the cranial nerve that runs from your brain to your inner ear and controls balance and hearing. Symptoms can include hearing loss, ringing in your ear, and unsteadiness.

diagnoses.name: Brain Tumor
diagnoses.description: A mass or growth of abnormal cells in your brain. Symptoms can vary greatly depending on the brain tumor's size, location and rate of growth. Common symptoms include headaches, seizures, numbness, weakness, and cognitive or personality changes.

diagnoses.name: Neuromyelitis Optica
diagnoses.description: Also known as Devic's disease, it's an autoimmune disorder in which the immune system attacks the optic nerves and spinal cord. Symptoms can include visual loss, weakness or paralysis in the legs or arms, painful spasms, and sometimes numbness.

diagnoses.name: Diabetes Mellitus
diagnoses.description: A metabolic disease that causes high blood sugar. Over time, excess glucose in your blood can lead to health problems, such as neuropathy (nerve damage) which can cause numbness. Diabetes can also lead to small vessel disease, which can be a cause of strokes or small bleeds in the brain, leading to a variety of neurological symptoms.

diagnoses.name: Hypothyroidism
diagnoses.description: A condition in which your thyroid gland doesn't produce enough thyroid hormones. Symptoms can include fatigue, increased sensitivity to cold, constipation, dry skin, weight gain, and muscle weakness. Brain fog, including headaches, can also be a symptom due to the body's slow metabolism.

diagnoses: B12 deficiency or other vitamin deficiencies
Evans Syndrome (Autoimmune Hemolytic Anemia with ITP)
Granulomatosis with Polyangiitis (GPA, formerly known as Wegener's Granulomatosis)
Rheumatoid Arthritis with secondary Sjögren's syndrome
Evans syndrome (autoimmune hemolytic anemia with immune thrombocytopenia)

diagnoses.name: Stevens-Johnson Syndrome/Toxic Epidermal Necrolysis
diagnoses.note: Overlap condition with toxic epidermal necrolysis as a severe form.

diagnoses.name: Systemic Lupus Erythematosus
diagnoses.note: May also present with lichen planus-like lesions.

diagnoses.name: Pemphigus Vulgaris
diagnoses.note: Autoimmune blistering disease; can sometimes result in postinflammatory dyspigmentation.

diagnoses.name: Bullous Pemphigoid
diagnoses.note: Autoimmune disorder which may cause postinflammatory dyspigmentation after the blisters heal.

diagnoses.name: Drug-induced Hemolytic Anemia
diagnoses.note: Some drugs can also induce skin reactions, potentially mimicking symptoms like lichen planus.

diagnoses.name: Graft vs Host Disease
diagnoses.note: May present with features similar to lichen planus and can also cause postinflammatory dyspigmentation.

diagnoses.name: Paroxysmal Nocturnal Hemoglobinuria
diagnoses.note: Though more rare, it's a condition that leads to hemolytic anemia.

diagnoses.name: Autoimmune Hemolytic Anemia
diagnoses.note: A condition where the body's immune system attacks its own red blood cells.

diagnoses.name: Porphyria Cutanea Tarda
diagnoses.note: Can cause blistering that leads to postinflammatory dyspigmentation; might be confused with other dermatologic conditions.

diagnoses.name: Lichen Planus-associated Hepatitis C
diagnoses.note: Hepatitis C can present with lichen planus as an extrahepatic manifestation.

diagnoses: Hepatitis B or C associated vasculitis
Vasculitis associated with infections (e.g., Hepatitis B/C, HIV)
Granulomatosis with Polyangiitis (formerly known as Wegener's Granulomatosis)
Hepatitis B or C with associated cryoglobulinemia

diagnoses.name: Systemic Lupus Erythematosus
diagnoses.description: A chronic autoimmune disease that can cause inflammation and pain in any part of your body. Central nervous system involvement can lead to seizures, and skin manifestations can include lichen planus-like lesions.

diagnoses.name: Rheumatoid Arthritis
diagnoses.description: A chronic inflammatory disorder affecting many joints, including those in the hands and feet. Can also involve skin symptoms and, rarely, neurological complications such as seizures.

diagnoses.name: Sjögren's Syndrome
diagnoses.description: An autoimmune disease that attacks the glands responsible for keeping the eyes, mouth, and other parts of the body moist. Neurological complications can lead to seizures and cognitive dysfunction simulating delirium.

diagnoses.name: Dermatomyositis
diagnoses.description: An inflammatory disease marked by muscle weakness and skin rash. The condition can involve the skin in a way that may resemble lichen planus and has been associated with other autoimmune disorders that can cause joint issues.

diagnoses.name: Systemic Sclerosis (Scleroderma)
diagnoses.description: An autoimmune rheumatic disease characterized by hardening and tightening of the skin and connective tissues. It can also affect internal organs and can present with symptoms such as arthralgia.

diagnoses.name: Mixed Connective Tissue Disease
diagnoses.description: This disease may manifest signs and symptoms similar to those of several connective tissue diseases — including systemic lupus erythematosus and scleroderma. Patients may present with symptoms like arthropathy and skin issues.

diagnoses.name: Vasculitis
diagnoses.description: An inflammation of the blood vessels, which can cause changes in the blood vessel walls, including thickening, weakening, narrowing, and scarring. Skin lesions similar to chilblain or lichen planus may occur.

diagnoses.name: Behçet's Disease
diagnoses.description: A rare disorder causing blood vessel inflammation throughout your body. The disease can lead to numerous signs and symptoms that may mimic other conditions, including skin lesions and joint pain.

diagnoses.name: Antiphospholipid Syndrome
diagnoses.description: An immune system disorder that causes an increased risk of blood clots. This condition can lead to neurological symptoms such as seizures and cognitive dysfunction.

diagnoses.name: Neurosyphilis
diagnoses.description: A bacterial infection of the brain or spinal cord. It usually occurs in persons who have had untreated syphilis for many years. Symptoms might include seizures and cognitive disturbances resembling delirium.

diagnoses: Viral Infections (such as HIV, Hepatitis C)
Inflammatory bowel disease (e.g., Crohn's disease, Ulcerative colitis)
Drug Reaction with Eosinophilia and Systemic Symptoms (DRESS) Syndrome
